mathematical_foundations_of_dimensional_.title: Mathematical Foundations of Dimensional Analysis
mathematical_foundations_of_dimensional_.objective: State and describe the mathematical principles behind dimensional analysis.
notes: Units are written inside a formula; quantities are actually a number multiplied by a unit
Units are treated similarly to numbers or variables, they can be added, multiplied, divided, etc.
The unit of your answer is based on the unit your provide
All physics are based on a few basic units: meters, kilograms, seconds, and coulombs
All conversion factors are equal to 1, and can be multiplied to manipulate units as you want.

conversion_factors_6.title: Conversion Factors 6
conversion_factors_6.subtitle: Using Conversion Factors with Formulas
conversion_factors_6.objective: Use conversion factors together with formulas to solve novel and nondirect problems.

dimensional_analysis_3.title: Dimensional Analysis 3
dimensional_analysis_3.subtitle: Using Dimensional Analysis to Confirm Equations
dimensional_analysis_3.objective: Confirm formulas and answers to symbolic algebra porblems with dimensional analysis.

derive_and_categorize_units.title: Derive and Categorize Units
derive_and_categorize_units.objective: Using physics formulas, derive all relevant physics quantities; categorize these quantities by their dimensions.

rounding.note: No whining, people dp it wrong all the time!

examples: voltage and current are directly proportional when resistance is constant
displacement is proportional to the square of time when acceleration is constant and initial velocity is zero

variable_transformations_2.objective: Algebraically modify a relationship a graph with a non-direct proportionality to a graph showing a direct proportionality in 3-4 algebraic steps; interpret the slope of the line of this graph.
examples: necessary to use a pendulum to measure free-fall acceleration

A good scientist can, in a small amount of space and without a calcualtor,
figure out an order of magnitude estimate of the answer.

examples: Explain why displacement and position  must be vectors but distance cannot be a vector.
Examine whether displacement depends upon the location of the origin and the direction of the axes.

parameters: Equations are not given on quiz.

quantitative_two_direction_kinematic_gra.title: Quantitative Two-Direction Kinematic Graphs 2
quantitative_two_direction_kinematic_gra.objective: Create position, velocity, and acceleration time graphs for objects moving with a constant acceleration but in two different directions and passing the origin.

fundamental_theorem_of_calculus_two_dire.objective: Fundamental Theorem of Calculus for Two-Direction Motion

forward_and_backward_kinematics_quantita.title: Forward and Backwards Kinematics
forward_and_backward_kinematics_quantita.need_to_add: Two direction quantitative kinematic graphs (3 and 4); derivations of kinematic equations (5)

lazy_donkey_paradox.objective: Defend how Newton's Third Law still applies when an object is broken by a force.

notes: Restate Newton's Third Law in which forces are not 'actions' and 'reactions' but always come in equal pairs.

Relate contact forces to electrostatic forces and use this relationship to defend Newton's Third Law for contact forces.

inertia_newtons_first_law.objective: Define inertia and relate inertia to mass

forces_on_you.limits: Will not include very difficult elevator problems.

the_electromagnetic_spectrum_analytical.title: The Electromagnetic Spectrum: Analytical
enduring_understandings: The electromagnetic spectrum contains seven types of electromagnetic waves, including visible light.
While all waves are experienced and applied in qualitatively different waves, they are all the same thing: oscillating electric and magnetic energy.
The only true differences amongst electromagnetic waves are quantitative values: wavelength, frequency, and photon energy
These three values are related by fundamental constants.
Frequency and energy are directly proportional, while wavelength is inversely proportional to both.

force_within_atoms.objective: Demonstrate why electrostatic, not gravitational force, determines the action of electrons within atoms.

simple_magnets.title: Simple Magnets
simple_magnets.objective: Recognize North and South poles of a magnet, predict attraction and repulsion in a magnet, recognize earth's magnetic field, explain how a compass works
simple_magnets.notes: north and south poles, earth's magnetic field, how a compass works.

simple_electromagnet.title: Simple Electromagnet
simple_electromagnet.objective: Explain how to build a simple electromagnet.

simple_magnetic_fields.title: Simple Magnetic Fields
simple_magnetic_fields.objective: Draw a magnetic field of a single bar magnet and of the earth.

how_do_magnets_work.title: How do magnets work?
how_do_magnets_work.objective: Explain and diagram how a magnet works.

electron_motion_in_magnetic_field.title: Electron motion in a magnetic field
electron_motion_in_magnetic_field.objective: Determine, using right-hand rules, how an electron moves within a magnetic field; recogniezze why a bar magnet lines up in an electric field.

magnetization_of_metal.title: Magnetization of metal
magnetization_of_metal.objective: Explain what happens on a subatomic level when a piece of metal is magnetized

earths_magnetic_field.title: Earth's Magnetic Field
earths_magnetic_field.objective: Explain why the earth has a magnetic field and identify crucial consequences of the earth's magnetic field.

dc_motors_electrical_generators.title: DC Motors and Electrical Generators
dc_motors_electrical_generators.objective: Using concepts of magnetic fields and electric current, explain how a DC motor and an electrical generator works.

multiple_magnetic_fields.title: Multiple Magnetic Fields
multiple_magnetic_fields.objective: Draw the magnetic field of two magnets and explain why they would attract or repel.

what_is_light.title: What is light?
what_is_light.objective: Narrate qualitatively why light exists using Faraday's Law, Ampere's Law, and other electromagnetic laws.

thermodynamics.title: Thermodynamics
thermodynamics.notes: These units need to be done together to be understood...for example, pods on definitions of temperature and pressure I wasn't sure where to include

kinetic_theory_of_matter_conceptual.title: Kinetic Theory of Matter Conceptual
notes: Many of these quizzes and examples need to be combined!
Does not include conduction, convection, and radiation, which must be added!

where_are_molecules_faster.title: Where are the molecules faster?
where_are_molecules_faster.objective: Recognize where molecules move faster between different options.

states_of_matter_1.title: States of Matter 1
states_of_matter_1.objective: Recognize how molecules move differently within different states of matter.

conduction_convection_radiation_1.title: Conduction, Convection, and Radiation 1
conduction_convection_radiation_1.objective: Recognize simple examples of heat transfer by conduction, convection, and radiation

air_pressure.title: Air Pressure
air_pressure.objective: Define air pressure, give examples of how air pressure applies, explain why humans do not feel air pressure, define atmospheric pressure.

where_molecules_are_faster_2.title: Where are the molecules faster 2
where_molecules_are_faster_2.objective: Describe where molecules move faster and give consequences of this; define temperature as average kinetic energy of molecules
where_molecules_are_faster_2.idea: Incorporate some of the level 1 quizzes into this.

define_temperature.title: Define Temperature
define_temperature.objective: Define temperature as the average kinetic enregy of molecules.

states_of_matter_2.title: States of Matter 2
states_of_matter_2.objective: Describe and draw diagrams showing how molecules move within each state of matter.

kinetic_theory_applications.title: Kinetic Theory Applications
kinetic_theory_applications.objective: Recognize and describe applications of the kinetic theory of matter
examples: Food coloring spreads faster in hot water
Smells spread faster in hot air.
Apply to thermal expansion
Apply to basic gas laws

entropy_1.title: Entropy 1
entropy_1.objective: Define entropy, give examples of high and low entropy, and state the second law of thermodynamics.

entropy_2.title: Entropy 2
entropy_2.objective: Answer more complex questions on entropy

define_kinetic_theory.title: Define the Kinetic Theory of Matter
define_kinetic_theory.objective: Define the kinetic theory of matter; relate to changes in temperature

changes_of_state.title: Changes of state
changes_of_state.objective: Explain what occurs on a molecular level during a change of state; explain why temperature does not change during a change of state

conduction_zeroth_law.title: Conduction and the Zeroth Law
conduction_zeroth_law.objective: Relate heat transfer by conduction to the zeroth law of thermodynamics, kinetic theory, and the mechanics of collisions

evaporation.title: Evaporation
evaporation.objective: Contrast evaporation and boiling; explain how water cools due to evaporation; explain evaporation in open and closed containers.

advanced_convection_and_radiation.title: Advanced Convection and Radiation
advanced_convection_and_radiation.objective: Relate heat radiation to our knowledge of electromagnetic waves

entropy_3.title: Entropy 3
entropy_3.objective: Compare random and non-random motion of molecules; describe entropy change in common examples of energy transfer

brownian_motion.title: Brownian Motion
brownian_motion.objective: Describe how molecules appear to be moving by not traveling in a random walk model.

entropy_probability.title: Entropy and Probability
entropy_probability.objective: Relate common processes to probability theory
examples: spreading perfume
jam mixed in pudding
entropy_probability.enrichment: Students should read/see the play 'Arcadia' by Tom Stoppard as a part of this lesson.

heat_formula_1.title: Heat Formula 1
heat_formula_1.objective: Determine the heat energy necessary to cause a temperature change.

thermal_contact_1.title: Thermal Contact 1: Zeroth Law of Thermodynamics
thermal_contact_1.objective: Recognize (multiple choice) how heat will move when two objects are in thermal contact; determine when such a process ends.

temperature_scales.title: Temperature Scales
temperature_scales.objective: Define the three (or four) temperature scales; give guidelines on temperature scale, know the difference between scales and units
examples: Where does water boil on each scale?
What would a hot day be on each scale?
What would a cold day be on each scale?
Why do we say 'degrees Celsius' and 'degrees Fahrenheit' but never 'degrees Kelvin', just 'Kelvin'

temperature_conversions.title: Temperature Conversions
temperature_conversions.objective: Use formulas to convert temperatures between the three temperature scales.

heat_formula_2.title: Heat Formula 2
heat_formula_2.objective: Solve the heat formula for mass or specific heat; determine what a material is based on specific heat.

heat_graphs.title: Heat Graphs
heat_graphs.objective: Draw qualitative graphs of temperature as heat is added; describe and explain what happens when state changes in these graphs.

thermal_contact_2.title: Thermal Contact 2
thermal_contact_2.objective: Determine how heat will move when two objects are in thermal contact; determine when such a process ends.

heat_formula_3.title: Heat Formula 3
heat_formula_3.objective: Solve heat formula problems asking for final or initial temperature.

heat_formula_4.title: Heat Formula 4: Multi-Step Problems
heat_formula_4.objective: Determine the amount of heat necessary to both head an object and change the state of matter of that object.

newtons_law_of_cooling.title: Newton's Law of Cooling
newtons_law_of_cooling.objective: Model the temperature of a cooling object as an exponential decay and connect this to the zeroeth law of thermodynamics.

heat_formula_5.title: Heat Formula 5: Multi-Step solve for tmperature
heat_formula_5.objective: Solve a problem using the heat formula in which an object changes state of matter and you must determine final or initial temperature.

heat_formula_mixture.title: Heat Formula Mixtures
heat_formula_mixture.objective: Determine the final temperature of a mixture; determine the heat capacity of an unknown substance by placing it in water.

quantitative_gas_laws_thermal_expansion.title: Quantitative Gas Laws and Thermal Expansion
quantitative_gas_laws_thermal_expansion.notes: I need more on proving the ideal gas law and connecting it to the combined gas law.

thermal_expansion_formulas.title: Thermal Expansion Formulas
thermal_expansion_formulas.objective: Use the formulas for thermal expansion of a solid or liquid.

gas_laws_1.title: Gas Laws 1
gas_laws_1.objective: Use gas laws built only on proportionality.
gas_laws_1.limits: Very straightforward mathematical problems; no solving for a denominator

gas_laws_2.title: Gas Laws 2
gas_laws_2.objective: Use gas laws built only on proportionality
gas_laws_2.limits: Includes more inconvientient numbers and mathematical situaitons, such as solving for the denominator

combined_gas_law.title: Combined Gas Law
combined_gas_law.objective: Defend and solve the combined gas law; differentiate between the combined gas law and the ideal gas law; explain why gas laws are ueful and necessary

thermal_expansion_advanced.title: Thermal Expansion Advanced
thermal_expansion_advanced.objective: Solve complex real world thermal expansion problems, such as the thermal expansion of the oceans.

prove_ideal_gas_law.title: Prove the Ideal Gas Law
prove_ideal_gas_law.objective: Through both mathematical and conceptual arguments, prove the ideal gas law from the combined gas law.

heat_processes.title: Heat Processes
heat_processes.idea: This unit will deal with heat processes on P-V graphs.

counting_parts_nucleus.title: Counting Parts of a Nucleus
counting_parts_nucleus.objective: Count the protons and neutrons in a nucleus; represent a nucleus in nuclide notation

atomic_mass_vs_mass_number.title: Atomic Mass vs. Mass Number
atomic_mass_vs_mass_number.objective: Differentiate between atomic mass and mass number; explain when each is useful

alpha_beta_decay.title: Alpha and Beta Decay
alpha_beta_decay.objective: Draw reactions involving alpha or beta decay of an isotope.

complete_nuclear_reaction.title: Complete a Nuclear Reaction
complete_nuclear_reaction.objective: Complete a nuclear reaction formula that has missing information; identify the reaction as fission, fuision, or decay.

simple_half_life.title: Simple Half Life
simple_half_life.limits: Problems in this seciton do not require the half-life to be represented as a function.
simple_half_life.example: If an isotope has a half-life of 3 years and you have 32 grams of the isotope, how much mass will you have after 9 years?

identify_crucial_particles.title: Identify Crucial Particles
identify_crucial_particles.objective: Identify the particles most crucial to understanding nuclear reactions.

written_reactions_1.title: Written Reactions 1
written_reactions_1.objective: For a written description of a nuclear reaction, write the reaction in a proper formula.
written_reactions_1.example: uranium-238 undergoes alpha decay, write the reaction; a hydrogen atom and an alpha particle fuse, write the reaction

written_reactions_2.title: Written Reactions 2
written_reactions_2.objective: For a written description of a nuclear reaction, write the reaction in a proper formula; determine energy released by a nuclear reaction.
written_reactions_2.notes: This crucial topic should be broken into two sections

half_life_formulas.title: Half-Life Formulas
half_life_formulas.objective: Represent half-life through an exponential decay function; use these formulas properly

calculate_atomic_mass.title: Calculate Atomic Mass
calculate_atomic_mass.objective: Calculate the atomic mass of an element from a weighted average of isotopes and explain the purpose of this calculation.

decay_chain.title: Decay Chain
decay_chain.objective: Use a table of isotopes to draft a decay chain for a particular isotope.

nuclear_reactions_sun.title: Nuclear Reactions in the Sun
nuclear_reactions_sun.objective: Write and analyze the nuclear reactions occuring inside the sun; explain how they produce energy.

remnants_isotope.title: Remnants of an Isotope
remnants_isotope.objective: Based upon the decay chain and the half-life of a particular isotope, identify at particualr times what different products you will have and what radiation they will give off.
remnants_isotope.notes: Good lead-in to a computation problem.

nuclear_reaction_basic_concepts.title: Nuclear Reaction Basic Concepts
nuclear_reaction_basic_concepts.objective: Identify parts of an atom; know that nuclear reactions occur only in the nucleus of the atom; define terms 'radioactive' and 'radioactivity

fission_fusion_decay.title: Fission, Fusion, and Decay
fission_fusion_decay.objective: Differentiate between three types of nuclear reactions: fission, fuision, and decay

nuclear_vs_chemical_reactions.title: Nuclear vs. Chemical Reactions
nuclear_vs_chemical_reactions.objective: Differentiate between nuclear and chemical reactions

nuclear_reaction_danger.title: Nuclear Reaction Danger
nuclear_reaction_danger.objective: Assess the danger of different types of nuclear reactions
nuclear_reaction_danger.notes: Requires previous knowledge of the electromagnetic spectrum.

nuclear_reactions_stars.title: Nuclear Reaction in the Stars
nuclear_reactions_stars.objective: Explain the processes of stars by using the concept of nuclear reaction.

artificially_created_elements_1.title: Artificially Created Elements 1
artificially_created_elements_1.objective: Explain how new elements can be artificially created; draw reactions that go with those examples.

artificially_created_elements_2.title: Artificially Created Elements 2
artificially_created_elements_2.objective: Explain more complex examples of how new elements can be artificially created; draw reactions that go with those examples.

isotopes_uranium.title: Isotopes of Uranium
isotopes_uranium.objective: Explain the importance of different isotopes of uranium for the creation of a nuclear reactor or a nuclear bomb; examine how different isotopes are isolated.

periodic_table_cosmology.title: Periodic Table Cosmology
periodic_table_cosmology.objective: Explain, using descriptions of reactions, how heavier elements within the universe can be created.

energy_levels.title: Energy Levels
energy_levels.objective: Determine the difference between different energy levels of an atom.

photons_atoms.title: Photons and Atoms
photons_atoms.objective: Explain how and why photons of a precise energy can be emitted or absorbed by an atom, refer to electrons and energy levels in your answer

energy_levels_photons.title: Energy Levels and Photons
energy_levels_photons.objective: Given an atom of various energy levels, determine the wavelength, frequency, and color or type of wave that can be emitted by that atom.

ionizing_radiation.title: Ionizing Radiation
ionizing_radiation.objective: Differentiate between ionizing and non-ionizing radiation

cell_phone_controversy.title: Cell Phone Controversy
cell_phone_controversy.objective: Evaluate the danger of devices that emit electromagnetic waves such as cellphones; defend choices using knowledge of atomic structure and electromagnetic waves.

bands_spectrum.title: Bands in Spectrum
bands_spectrum.objective: Given a spectrum showing bands of particualr wavelengths, recognize the bands by consutling a table of energy levels.

neon_lights.title: Neon Lights
neon_lights.objective: Use the chemical composition of a neon tube to determine what color a neon light will shine.

astrochemistry.title: Astrochemistry
astrochemistry.objective: Determine the chemical composition of an astronomical body using a spectrum of taht body and a table of energy levels between atoms; defend choices.

basic_quantum_theory.title: Basic Quantum Theory
basic_quantum_theory.notes: A brief introduction to some concepts that would be covered in a college quantum mechanics course, but not including solutions to the Schrodinger equation.

recognize_energy_types.title: Recognize Energy Types
recognize_energy_types.objective: Recognize (multiple choice) single examples of different types of energy

write_energy_types.title: Write Energy Types
write_energy_types.objective: Write the names of different types of energy.

state_law_conservation_of_energy.title: State the Law of Conservation of Energy
state_law_conservation_of_energy.objective: State, from memory, the law of conservation of energy.

recognize_energy_transfer.title: Recognize Energy Transfer
recognize_energy_transfer.objective: Recognize (multiple choice) processes of 2-3 steps in which energy changes from one type to another; name these processes

describe_energy_transfer_1.title: Describe Energy Transfer 1
describe_energy_transfer_1.objective: Write, using tables as guidance, processes of 2 - 3 steps in which energy changes from one type to another; name these processes.

describe_energy_transfer_2.title: Describe Energy Transfer 2
describe_energy_transfer_2.objective: Write without guidance energy transfer in four or more steps; name processes involved.
describe_energy_transfer_2.example: Describe how the energy contained in natural gas is converted to light energy from a light bulb.

connect_energy_to_sun.title: Connect Energy to Sun
connect_energy_to_sun.objective: Connect (nearly) all forms of energy on earth back to light from the sun.
connect_energy_to_sun.notes: The exceptions, which should be noted, are geothermal and nuclear energy.

connect_energy_to_dust.title: Connect Energy to Dust
connect_energy_to_dust.objective: Connect energy of the earth back to the gravitational potential energy of space dust (which would eventually form the sun)
connect_energy_to_dust.connections: Requires knowledge of gravitation and nuclear physics
